Congruences on completely 0-simple semigroups
This chapter describes the implementation of congruences on completely 0-simple semigroups in the &Semigroups; package, and the functions associated with them. This code and this part of the manual were written by Michael Torpey. Most of the theorems used in this chapter are from Section 3.5 of .
By the Rees Theorem, any 0-simple semigroup S is isomorphic to a Rees 0-matrix semigroup (see ) over a group, with a regular sandwich matrix.
That is, S \cong \mathcal{M}^0[G; I,\Lambda; P], where G is a group, \Lambda and I are non-empty sets, and P is regular in the sense that no two of its rows or columns contain only zeroes.
That is, S is isomorphic to M^0[G; I,L; P] where G is a group, L and I are non-empty sets and the matrix P is regular in the sense that no two of its rows or columns contain only zeroes.
Congruences by Linked Triple A linked triple of such a semigroup is a triple of the form (N,\mathcal{S},\mathcal{T}) (N,S,T) where
N is a normal subgroup of the underlying group G,
\mathcal{S}S is an equivalence relation on the columns of P,
\mathcal{T}T is an equivalence relation on the rows of P,
satisfying the following conditions:
A pair of \mathcal{S}S-related columns must contain zeroes in precisely the same rows.
A pair of \mathcal{T}T-related rows must contain zeroes in precisely the same columns.
If (i,j) \in \mathcal{S} and (u,v) \in \mathcal{T}, such that the matrix entries p_{\lambda i}, p_{\lambda j}, p_{\mu i}, p_{\mu j} \neq 0, then q_{\lambda \mu i j} \in N, where q_{\lambda \mu i j} = p_{\lambda i} p_{\mu i}^{-1} p_{\mu j} p_{\lambda j}^{-1}.
If (i,j) is in S, (u,v) is in T, and the matrix entries p_ui, p_uj, p_vi, and p_vj are all non-zero, then q_uvij is in N, where q_uvij = p_ui * p_vi^-1 * p_vj * p_uj^-1.
By Theorem 3.5.9, there is a bijection between the set of non-universal congruences of a finite 0-simple Rees 0-matrix semigroup, and the set of its linked triples. In this way, we can internally represent any congruence of such a semigroup by storing its associated linked triple instead of a set of generating pairs, and thus perform many calculations on it more efficiently.
If a congruence is defined by a linked triple (N,\mathcal{S},\mathcal{T}) (N,S,T) then a single class of that congruence can be defined by a triple (Nx,i/\mathcal{S},\lambda/\mathcal{T}), (Nx,i/S,u/T), where Nx is a right coset of N, i/\mathcal{S} is an equivalence class of columns under \mathcal{S}, and \lambda / \mathcalu/{T} is an equivalence class of rows under \mathcal{T}. Thus we can internally represent any class of such a congruence as a triple simply consisting of a right coset and two positive integers.

Universal Semigroup Congruences
The linked triples of a completely 0-simple Rees 0-matrix semigroup describe only its non-universal congruences. In any one of these, the zero element of the semigroup is related only to itself. However, for any semigroup S there must exist the universal congruence S \times xS. We must therefore represent this in a different way from the other congruences.
Since many things we want to calculate about congruences are trivial in the case of the universal congruence, this package contains a category specifically designed for it, IsUniversalSemigroupCongruence. This allows for universal semigroup congruences to be described together with the linked triples, to be compared and used together in functions. We also define IsUniversalSemigroupCongruenceClass, which acts as the single congruence class of the universal congruence.
